header: "For Donald Trump, Money Is Something the Banks Magically Conjure Up"
article:
The virus crisis will strengthen the dollar, argues economic historian Adam Tooze. And Europe will be weakened – in part because of Germany's resistance to coronabonds.
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
How the coronavirus is relentlessly exposing design flaws in
the common currency union and why the pandemic is a crisis of modernity: An
interview with Adam Tooze, an economic historian at Columbia University in New
York and author of the bestseller "Crashed: How a Decade of Financial
Crises Changed the World."
ZEIT
ONLINE: Mr. Tooze, as a historian, you study the great crises of
humankind. What is happening right now?
AdamTooze:
This crisis will change the world. In 1992, James Carville, Bill Clinton’s
chief adviser, coined the phrase: It’s the economy, stupid. It sounded
perfectly wise and reasonable. But we know today that it isn’t true. We are prepared
to paralyze entire economies to protect the risk groups, the elderly and people
with pre-existing conditions. The specific aim is to prevent overloading the
health-care system by any means necessary. You might say that we are dealing
with a second-order crisis. It’s not the disease itself, but the measures taken
to combat it that are threatening prosperity. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Was that different in the past? 
Tooze: I have
studied the files from the time of the Spanish influenza in 1918 in great
detail. It’s really interesting: From a medical standpoint, the crisis at the
time was much worse. It primarily hit young, working people. The Treaty of
Versailles was negotiated in the midst of the epidemic, the war economy was
being wound down and the postwar order was being shaped. Around 50 million
people died globally, but it was hardly a major political issue at the time,
except when U.S. President Woodrow Wilson fell ill. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: One could also view it as a civilizational step forward
that more focus has been placed on the suffering of the victims. 
Tooze: I would
see it as a crisis of modernity. A hundred years ago, there was no welfare
state in the modern sense, and the government didn’t feel the same
responsibility for public health. Hospitals didn’t play the central role in
life and death that they do today. Our medical capacities and expectations
create a completely new environment for making decisions: Do we risk the lives
of millions of people? Or do we allow the global economy to slide into a
depression? It still isn’t clear to many people how close we came to a
financial meltdown in March. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: How so? 
Tooze: Financial
markets anticipated the economic consequences of global lockdowns and panicked.
That was the third-order crisis. People just started selling everything, even
absolutely safe investments like German government bonds. The only reason there
wasn't a crash is because central banks intervened far more massively than in
2008. They have literally flooded the world with liquidity, particularly the
Federal Reserve, which responded extremely precisely and quickly, thus ensuring
the global supply of dollars. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: We should see the Fed as a kind of benevolent world
economic government? 
Tooze: I'm certain
there are far-sighted people in the Fed who want to do their best for
humankind. But in concrete terms, this is about the global nature of the American
bond market. The Fed wants to prevent foreign investors from selling their
bonds due to a shortage of dollars. This in turn stabilizes the international
financial markets. I believe that this crisis will reinforce the U.S. monetary hegenmony.
Even under an isolationist president like Donald Trump, investors can be
certain that the central bank will do what is necessary. This will strengthen
the dollar as the world’s reserve currency. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: That would be bad news for those in Europe who want to
establish the euro as a competitor in order to break American dominance on the
currency markets. 
Tooze: Europe
will emerge financially weakened from this crisis. The impression from outside
is that, even in the face of a challenge of this nature, not everyone is
pulling together. Why would long-term investors want to do business in euros?
The pandemic is relentlessly exposing the design flaws in the monetary union. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Still, European Union finance ministers did agree last week
on 500 billion euros in aid for member states in need, including access to the
funds in the European Stability Mechanism, the euro-zone’s backstop. 
Tooze: The ESM
is a product of the euro crisis, and its loans were tied to strict reform
conditions. Even if these conditions are now to be relaxed, it is still
considered politically toxic in large parts of Southern Europe. The crisis
makes clear that ultimately, in the absence of any real political agreement,
the monetary union will be held together by monetary infusions from the
European Central Bank. It is buying up eurozone bonds on a grand scale and
thereby keeping interest rates low. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Just as the United States is doing. 
Tooze: But with
one crucial difference. In the U.S., the Federal Reserve’s interventions are
closely coordinated with the U.S. Treasury. The crisis package passed by
Congress includes $454 billion to cover possible losses made by the Fed. The
situation is similar in Britain, where the Bank of England is now financing the
state directly. In a state-controlled monetary system, the central bank also
has to make its contribution in fighting the crisis. That’s the philosophy. But
in Europe, this has a politically destabilizing effect. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Why? 
Tooze: Because
a different logic applies in a monetary union. The ECB is responsible for 19 countries,
not one. This means that, in principle, transfers from one country to the
others can be organized through the central bank’s balance sheet. 
However, that isn’t compatible with the concept, pushed
through above all by Germany, of the eurozone as being a community of states
that are largely responsible for their own fiscal policies. That’s why the ECB
is legally prohibited from providing direct financing to member states. And it
leads to a bizarre situation in which the central bank has to justify its
actions with all sorts of flimsy arguments. Then the critics from Germany come
and say: That’s all nonsense – we’re going to take this to the German Federal
Constitutional Court. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Is it nonsense? 
Tooze: Of
course, it's nonsense. The bond purchases result in a mutualization of risks. That
is a fact. And this puts the Constitutional Court judges in a position where
they must produce circuitous arguments to give the ECB carte blanche, because the
euro would probably be history if the German high court were to declare the ECB's
policy to be illegal. And then, Berlin can claim that it didn’t have to
surrender the fiscal sovereignty of the Bundestag. It’s a Hall of Mirrors. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Your argument is that it's not an honest approach? 
Tooze: Yes. It
reminds me of the German position on security policy. The Germans say: We want
sovereignty, but we are not prepared to bear the cost of it – in the form of
higher military spending, for example. And then, when that stupid Trump
presents us with the bill, we look the other way. The people at the ECB are
experts. They know what they are doing. The German government relies on the
functional effectiveness of these measures, but in return, it accepts a spiral
of political de-legitimization that come along with them.  
ZEIT
ONLINE: Why is that, do you think? 
Tooze: I think
it has something to do with the obsessive focus on the status quo. You tell
yourself: Everything is going just fine, and as long as we maintain the
appearance that all is well, we don’t have to worry. But there are people who
are concerned. This results in the opening of a flank at the center of society
for the right-wing populist party Alternative for Germany, which exploits this
weakness with relish. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: What would you suggest? 
Tooze: I would suggest
putting an end to the deception. The Europeans should issue common bonds,
corona bonds, to help overcome the crisis. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: But the AfD would also seek to exploit that decision. 
Tooze: Certainly.
But if you believe in democracy, you must at least try to find majorities for such
a deepening of Europe. That is my criticism of Angela Merkel and of German
finance minister Olaf Scholz. I know he understands it. And I know that smart
people on his staff also understand it. So, why doesn’t he say: I trust my
powers of persuasion and I am prepared to put my career on the line for this. I
don’t think Germans are dumb. You can explain things to them. 
ZEIT ONLINE: Scholz
would probably say: Why take this risk if there’s another way? 
Tooze: I think
that’s too short-sighted. Following the initiative taken by nine European
governments for corona bonds, it is no longer possible to pretend that the
issue isn’t on the table. You have to think of it as a long-term relationship. Things
are going pretty well, but then the question arises: Should we get married? That’s
precisely what this initiative is, at least figuratively speaking. If you then
answer "no," as the German government does, there is no return to the
status quo. It’s a different game then. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Perhaps it’s a mistake to ask the question at all. 
Tooze: That may
be. That is something for future historians to judge. Perhaps they will arrive
at the conclusion that it's the kind of activism that is not untypical of
Emmanuel Macron. The impression right now is that Germany has decided to leave
France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Belgium and Ireland in the lurch. In situations
like this, you have to be conscious of the historical dimensions. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: The German position is being harshly criticized, especially
in Italy. Rightly so?
Tooze: I can at
least understand it. It's a distortion of the facts to say that Italians just
throw their money away. Italy has been practicing austerity for practically a
quarter of a century. With the exception of the 2009 crisis, the Italian state
has generated budgetary surpluses for the past 25 years, if you deduct interest
payments made to service sovereign debt. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: That debt still exceeds annual gross domestic product. 
Tooze: But it's
a legacy of the 1980s and '90s. The present generation cannot be held
responsible, and not in the moral sense either. The country is now being
governed by people with whom a deal should be made. The problem is that there
is much greater suffering in Southern Europe than in Northern Europe – and
this, too, is related to the monetary union's design flaws. In severe
crises, investors park their money in Germany, where it is considered safe. But
money is pulled out of countries like Italy. This results in completely
different world views. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Did Helmut Kohl overestimate German solidarity when he
introduced the euro? Or, put another way: Should the common currency have been
introduced at all? 
Tooze: Helmut
Kohl viewed himself as a historical figure and historical figures are gamblers.
Introducing the euro was a huge risk. Even at the time, it was possible to see
that further steps toward integration would be necessary for the monetary union
to work – and that the approval of the German population would be needed. But
that was of no interest to Kohl. But it was also a risk for other countries. They
gambled on the fact that the Germans would be prepared to make concessions. This
made conflict inevitable.   
The battle that France and Italy have won is the battle for
the ECB. It was conceived as a copy of Germany’s central bank, the Bundesbank,
but it hasn't been since the presidency of Mario Draghi. This bothers
conservatives in Germany and makes further progress on the European budget and
joint bonds even more difficult. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: A weakened Europe and a stronger U.S.: Will this be the
geopolitical result of the crisis? 
Tooze: The U.S.
has been strengthened in one particular area: monetary policy. Otherwise, the
pandemic has hit the American societal system at its weakest point: the health-care
system. Opinions may diverge over the American labor market, with its virtually
non-existent protections against dismissal, but it works. Unemployment is
currently rising at a breathtaking rate, but it will also fall relatively
quickly, if the economy bounces back. 
The health-care system is a different matter. It’s not
working. It is obvious that China and other Asian countries have dealt with the
disease better, even if there are doubts about the numbers the Chinese are
providing. This will not be without consequences. The crisis will further
strengthen the feeling that an Asian Century has dawned. The only Apple Stores
in the world that are open right now are those in China. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Could there be a renaissance in welfare-state thinking? 
Tooze: For the
U.S., at least, The New Deal candidate was Bernie Sanders, and he’s now out of
the race. For the American left, this marks the end of a history that began
with the Occupy Wall Street movement. However, it could be that a shift of that
kind will take place unexpectedly. When 17 million Americans lose their jobs in
just three weeks’ time, nobody knows what is going to happen. Or what happens
when a state like Michigan suddenly has a 25 percent unemployment rate. And it
will get worse. The interesting thing is that the aid packages that have thus
far been agreed upon are comparatively socially balanced relative to the
Republicans’ recent tax cuts. The assistance is more than just gifts to the
rich. They are financed by huge deficits. 
ZEIT ONLINE: That
means more debt. 
Tooze: And it
is likely that these debts will be used by conservatives to justify drastic
austerity measures. The debts accumulated today will be the cross to which any
form of welfare-state policy will be nailed. I believe that progressive forces won't
be able to get around a new approach to the issue of debt. You have to be
frank: Public debt is conceptually different from private debt. You don’t have
to pay it back. If necessary, you can simply park it in the Fed’s accounts and
leave it there. And there’s one politician who understands that extremely well. 
ZEIT
ONLINE: Who? 
Tooze: Donald
Trump. For him, money is something the banks magically conjure up. and he is
the chief magician. 
Translated by Daryl Lindsey
This interview has been edited and condensed for length and 
clarity. This is the English translation of the original German version.
